summary: This is a government motion filed by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, addressed to Magistrate Judge Henry Pitman, arguing for the pre-trial detention of Jeffrey Epstein. It details the serious charges of sex trafficking of minors, Epstein's extreme wealth and international travel as a flight risk, and concerns about witness intimidation. It references the prior Florida investigation and non-prosecution agreement. This is a government memorandum submitted to Magistrate Judge Henry Pitman opposing bail for Jeffrey Epstein. It argues Epstein poses an exceptionally high risk of flight and danger to the community, citing his vast wealth, international ties, prior conviction, alleged witness tampering, and evidence seized from his New York mansion.

events.title: Federal Indictment Returned
events.description: A federal grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned a sealed indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with one count of sex trafficking of minors and one count of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Prior Florida Investigation
events.description: Local police in Palm Beach, Florida, investigated Epstein for similar sex offenses against minor girls, which later involved federal authorities (U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI's Miami Office).

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding the investigation into his abuse of minor girls in Palm Beach.

events.title: Epstein's Extensive International Travel
events.description: In the 18 months prior to his arrest, Epstein traveled abroad via private jet on approximately more than 20 occasions, demonstrating significant international connections and mobility.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport upon arriving on a private international flight after a three-week stay abroad.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty in Florida state court to one count of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution, becoming a registered sex offender.

events.title: Search of Epstein's New York Mansion
events.description: Law enforcement searched Epstein's Manhattan mansion pursuant to warrants, discovering hundreds to thousands of sexually suggestive photographs of females, some appearing to be underage, and evidence consistent with victim accounts.

events.title: Government Bail Opposition Filed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY filed this memorandum opposing Epstein's release on bail, arguing he is a flight risk and danger to the community.

events.title: Alleged Witness Tampering in Florida
events.description: During the Florida investigation, there were credible allegations Epstein engaged in witness tampering, harassment, and hired PIs who forced a victim's father off the road, leading to plea discussions on obstruction charges.

keyFacts: The government alleges Jeffrey Epstein engaged in a years-long scheme to sexually abuse dozens of minor girls, some as young as 14, at his properties in New York and Florida, paying them in cash and encouraging them to recruit other victims.

Epstein is described as extraordinarily wealthy, owning at least six residences worldwide (including a private island), multiple vehicles, and at least two private jets capable of intercontinental travel, creating an extreme flight risk.

The motion argues the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida does not bind the Southern District of New York, especially as the new indictment includes victims and conduct in New York not covered by the prior agreement.
The government expresses serious concern that if released on bail, Epstein could attempt to pressure, intimidate, or obstruct witnesses and victims, posing a danger to the community.
Epstein faces a potential maximum prison sentence of up to 45 years for the charged offenses, which the government argues provides a powerful incentive for him to flee.

The government argues Jeffrey Epstein poses an 'exceptionally high' risk of flight due to his vast wealth, international contacts, access to private planes, and lack of meaningful ties to the district.

A search of Epstein's New York mansion on July 6-7, 2019, revealed hundreds to thousands of sexually suggestive photographs of females, with some appearing to be of underage girls, found in a locked safe.
Epstein is a registered Level 3 sex offender in New York from a 2008 Florida conviction for procuring a minor for prostitution, which the government cites as evidence of continued danger.
The document details past allegations of witness tampering and obstruction by Epstein during the Florida investigation, including his private investigators forcing a victim's father off the road.
The government states that discussions during the Florida case included Epstein potentially pleading guilty to obstruction (18 U.S.C. ยง 1512) and harassment charges.
